+666Tomato666 The array is just called a block and there's only so many 
block types making them work with any hard drive size and hard drive or ssd.

+biohazard737 Basically the file formats get sent into a continuous stream 
of information which are blocks.
The filesystem takes cares of reading where the blocks are, what they 
contain and in what order.
The kernel then works with the fs(filesystem) to load and get the 
information in the correct order to be operated on.
This is basically the physical side of the hard drive system.

A good example would be the relation of the linux kernel and ext4, Read on 
that ,It'll answer more than I could in a comment

+biohazard737 That's because this is the job of a file system, not the disk 
itself. Hard drivers (both the HDD and SSD type) just present to operating 
system a single array, with each cell holding a byte of information (I'm 
simplifying here a bit). This is an abstraction layer that allows file 
systems then work with any kind of drive, be it containing one or many 
spinning platers or a Flash memory based one, like SSD.

+biohazard737 "how it reads a picture file vs a video". The hard disk makes 
no distinction between file formats, it simply reads data at the operating 
system's request. It is the OS's job to interpret what that data represents.

+Sam Barkley It's a complex topic (programming) and software and data are 
separate things.
A software is an executable file (.exe), which consists of a list of 
commands for the processor, stored in a file (i.e .exe).
A data file is just data, like text, picture, etc. Both reside on the HDD. 
Both (and everything) is stored in binary (0s,1s).

Programming is complex but basically everything is hierarchical (starting 
from the simple and building on top of them, level by level).
There are low-level and high-level programming languages, they mark the two 
extremes of this hierarchy.
Ultimately everything is binary, but even programmers couldn't work with 0s 
and 1s. 
Low-level lngs do that, they access the built-in registers of every CPU and 
command them directly.
With it one can only create simple, basic commands, nothing complex.
High-level lngs include several more steps in the process, each step built 
on the previous.

I could explain it like this: Say you want your program to draw a triangle.
It is ultimately pixels at certain coordinates...
You can write "functions", pieces of codes with names, that you can always 
reuse. Like the SUM(A1,C1) function in Excel... someone programmed what SUM 
will do and you just need to write SUM not the actual code later.
But in programming the programmer uses the functions, the end user sees the 
triangle :)

So you write a function say DrawTriangle(a,b,c) and define what it does. 
(once written, you can use this for your program like 
DrawTriangle(coordinate1,c2,c3))
But inside defining this triangle function, what do you do? You need to 
draw 3 lines between the coordinates.
So this function only has 3 commands: You "call" (use, refer to) a line 
drawing function:
DrawLine(a,b)
DrawLine(b,c)
DrawLine(a,c)

But Inside the line function, what do you do? 
You need to draw many pixels between two coordinates (=a line). So here you 
will have more than 3 commands- you will do complex calculations to find 
out which pixels on your monitor fall in line with the imaginary line 
between x and y:
<caluclating "Coordinate">
DrawPixel(Coordinate)
and repeating (with calculations and a "loop" (cycle) for as many pixels is 
needed.

But the DrawPixel function has to be written as well, which is way more 
complicated, from taking control of the screen, videocard, its memory, 
initialize a video mode (fullscreen at a given resolution, where Windows 
can't draw over), use the video card's memory at a certain address from 
which a monitor will refresh the content (draw the content on screen) etc 
etc. which are all low level, binary, complex.

This is the hierarchy. It gets more and more technical.
At one end is the tiniest step of a command to the CPU or videocard (and 
many of them), at the very end is the one "DrawTriangle" function. I mean 
you will use more "higher level" functions that are built on previous 
pre-written ones.

Some pr. lngs have pixel drawing capabilites, some use Windows windows, 
some use DirectX and have built-in "DrawTriangle"-like functions, etc.
So with different programming languages you realize the same idea different 
ways (e.g. to just draw a triangle). Each lng codes the result to CPU 
commands differently, but each does, and ultimately everything is binary.
Imagine if instead of writing DrawTriangle, you would have to write 100x as 
many low level CPU commands. It's impossible.

I hope this shed a bit of light on what binary, commands, files, etc are.

No, universal translators or interpreters will not be possible in a very, 
very, very, very long time, if ever. A machine will never (or at least it 
will take literal aeons to accomplish it) be able to understand and convey 
into a target language, the infinite number of nuances of one single source 
language. Sarcasm, irony, humor, and understanding idiomatic expressions 
between tongues, among other language aspects, are things machines will 
probably never be able to replicate.

I personally think languages and the way we as a species produce and utter 
them are what make us human, more than any other aspect of our 
individuality as a kind or race. This "human" distinction becomes even more 
apparent when you add the aforementioned sarcasm, irony, humor, and 
idiomatic expressions to the mix. We are unique in that we can communicate 
through mouth movements that produce organized, standardized sounds that in 
turn serve as a channel and means of mutual comprehension between beings of 
our own species, and we can do it in different relays (namely languages). 
What other living being in our planet can do that? How can a machine be 
able to emulate eternities of evolution, especially when languages 
themselves continue to evolve as we do? It will most likely never happen... 
ever.?

I hope this discussion doesn't derail too quickly, there are a handful of 
interesting points worth going over. I do agree that the WWW does influence 
language change in various ways, it most likely does not stop or slow 
English language change. the grammatical and syntactical structure of 
language do change very slowly, but words coming in and out of use, 
pronounciation and loanword integration all happen at a much faster pace, 
and the introduction of the web has not stopped this process at all. In 
fact, I'd argue it has sped it up, as it simplifies language exchange and 
integration.  

While we are continually connected in these days, we still have our own 
culture and society we belong to, and these influence our language use 
immensly. 

Your objective definition of language is interesting, but does not fit its 
the concept as a whole. Language is also used in various other ways aside 
from expressing ideas/emotions. If that was the case, implicatures and 
indirect speech would not be a thing. We also use language to command, to 
suggest, to gain attention, to manipulate, to take action (e.g. "I now 
pronounce you husband and wife", or "I promise I will"), to provoke thought 
with language manipulation
 and many other functions. You might argue those are all results of 
expressing ideas, but that is not true, as in cases like above, you do not 
have the intent of expressing an idea. A better (though still flawed) 
analogy would be to compare language to a multitool, with little parts that 
make different tools which can be utilised for different ends.

Oh, one final note. This doesn't really address your main point, but it is 
relevant for the discussion itself. at one point, you said in your reply 
the following:

"I see it as the many different ways to write the number 7."
I wouldn't say different languages are all different variants to describe 
the same thing, because the different manners of describing things (be it 
abstract or concrete) actually cause the description to be very different 
as well. To illustrate this, consider how Russian uses no definite or 
indefinite articles, creating ambiguity and/or a more general sentence in 
some cases. Another example would be how a language like Dutch has the word 
"gezelligheid". It can be roughly described as a feeling of comfyness and 
joy in a social situation, but it is not directly translatable in any way, 
creating a different description altogether when you try to do so.

Whether inter-/extra-lingual diversity is a good thing or not is something 
I'm personally neutral about, so I'm not going to comment on that.

original mother language. Eventually, as new generations grow up, everyone 
would use the same language as their first language, right?" Yes, but aside 
from the fact that it is pretty inhumane to force it upon people, it is 
also difficult to give up a language because it is intertwined with culture 
and tradition. 

Then there's the problem of long-term language development. Every language 
changes on the long term. Look at Middle English from the 15th century and 
you'll quickly realize it is practically incomprehensible for the modern 
day English speaker. If everyone would adopt the same language, you would 
quickly see the rise of different dialects and variations (caused mainly by 
regional variation), and eventually new languages can be created because of 
it. It's impossible and undesireable to keep a language exactly the same.

happens to be more common in winter for a host of reasons.

point where almost everything we know is true? That has never been the case

They synch up temporarily because that's how any group of varying cycles 
works.

You know blinkers in cars? The turn signal blinker? Even though pace of 
blinking is consistent for an individual car, different cars have blinkers 
that blink on a slightly different cadence. Think about a bunch of cars 
stopped at a traffic light, waiting to turn. All the blinkers are on in all 
the cars. Some of them will blink at the same time, or close to it for a 
few blinks. Then they won't be synched with those fellow blinkers and will 
synch up with other blinkers and then won't be synched... and on and on.

multiple, slightly varying cycles, to compare to each other.

+Mosco Monster Not quite. The rate as which the distance increases per unit 
time can be bigger than the speed of light, but this does not necessarily 
mean that you can't reach them traveling at the speed of light. Once you 
are partway, the space behind you expands as well. You need to know exactly 
how the expansion of the universe depends on time to know for sure and even 
then the calculation can have a very unexpected result.

The distance (measured at the time you start) to the furthest object you 
can reach is given by the integral from the current time to inifinity of 
c/a(t)dt , where a(t) is the scale factor. 

If for example a(t) ~ k*t, then you can actually reach any part of the 
universe since the integral of 1/x dx diverges, even though any object 
further away than the distance c/k "moves away from you faster than light".

Of course, that integral diverges only logarithmically and we'd be talking 
about huge timescales proportional to exp(distance) - 1, but it is possible 
in principle.

from oversimplification. The Glagolitic alphabet, which is shown first, has 
never been used in Rus. It is an *original* alphabet, *not* based on any 
Greek scripts and it has been developed by the brothers St. Cyril and St. 
Methodius at the behest of Byzantine Emperor Michael III for their 
religious mission to Great Moravia. Much later after their deaths their 
students fled to Bulgaria, where the now known Cyrillic alphabet was 
*derived* from the Greek alphabet *probably* by those same students of St. 
St. Cyril and Methodius. The alphabet was enhanced with a *few* special 
letters for sounds, which Greek does not need. Those letters *partially* 
come from the Glagolitic alphabet, some are inventions or modifications of 
Greek letters. Nevertheless the Cyrillic alphabet was developed *especially* 
for the religious and governing needs of the First Bulgarian Empire, more 
than 100 years before Vladimir I decided to adopt Christianity.?

the last person is informed of his/her color.

Technically, the aliens state in the video that no "signal" can be sent, 
and that the people must "guess" their hat color. These conditions preclude 
the solution given in the video, by which the first man uses the word 
'black' or 'white' to "signal" an odd number of hats of that color to the 
other people who would give their answers after him, based on that signal. 
That is most definitely conveying information and is most definitely a 
"signal." Furthermore, all the other people are able to deduce from this 
"signaled" information, combined with the inadvertently conveyed 
information of the color given by the subsequent persons, their own hat 
color. These are most definitely NOT "guesses." They are logical deductions 
with 100% accuracy rate, assuming no human error on the part of the 
previous persons in line. So, techincally the given solution fails those 
two criteria. It involves a signal, and does not involve any guesses.
But to be fair, those rules especially the one insisting on "guesses" 
preclude any possible solution, since any solution which guaranteed success 
could not be guessing. If, therefore, we choose to interpret the rules more 
leniently to allow the solution given in the video, i.e., to not prohibit 
that sort of signal given and to allow non-guess answers, then two other 
solutions offered in comments below work just as well.
One is the time delay solution mentioned by at least 2 people. And the 
other is the rather humorous solution of taking off your hat and looking at 
it.
The only rules violated by the time delay solution are exactly the rules of 
signaling and guessing, the same two rules violated and to the exact same 
degree, and in almost the exact same way, by the given binary-code 
solution. So those two solutions are exactly equally valid.
As for the looking-at-your-hat solution (lol), this is, in fact, 
technically the best solution. Why? Because it violates the fewest of the 
given rules. Like the other two solutions, it violates the "guessing" rule, 
sine you are not "guessing" the color of your hat if you looked at it. But 
unlike the other two solutions, it does not also violate the "signal" rule, 
since it sends no signal.
Since this solution violates only ONE rule and the other two solutions each 
violate TWO rules, this looking-at-your-hat solution, ironically, is 
technically the best of the three.

I have a different answer. Took me longer to get, but here it is...

Realize that black or white is a binary choice, meaning we can represent 
the line up as a binary digit. Let black be 1, and white be 0.

Simplify the problem into a 3-person scenario.

Therefore, the binary digit for this line up ranges from 000 to 111 (or 0 
to 7 in decimal).

Assume everyone is wearing black hats. Therefore, the answer is 111 (7 in 
decimal).

From the perspective of the first player, they see two blacks. Then, the 
number in this case is either 011 or 111 (either 3 or 7).

Magically assume that the first person in line gets the color of their hat 
right.

From the perspective of the second player, they know the color behind them 
is black, and in front is black. So they know the number is 101 or 111 (5 
or 7 in decimal).

Magically assume that the second person in line gets the color of their hat 
right.

From the perspective of the third player, they know the color of the two 
hats behind them are black. So the number is either 110 or 111 (6 or 7 in 
decimal).

Now, assuming that the first person guesses their hat correctly, notice how 
every person in the line will all think of two different numbers -- either 
the right one, or the wrong one. They will all think of different wrong 
numbers, and all will think of the same right number.

Notice also that the right number is always higher (in this case) than the 
wrong number.

The key is therefore:
1) To remove the first person from the number (so the 3-digit number 
becomes a 2-digit number), and
2) To have the first person be able to hint "higher" or "lower" for all the 
rest of the players of the line to correctly figure out what the number is. 
Say black is higher, white is lower.

Let's test this idea:

Take the case of all white hats. Three people in line. Assume everyone is 
intelligent.

First person sees two white hats. Then the number is 00 (0 in decimal).

First person knows the second person will see 1 white hat, and so will 
think the answer is either 10 or 00 (2 or 0 in decimal).

First person knows the third person will hear "white" behind them (if the 
second person correctly calculated) and so will think the answer is either 
01 or 00 (1 or 0 in decimal).

First person knows that among the possible answers everybody can think of, 
the lower answer is correct.

First person says "white"

Second person knows to choose the lower number from whatever they are 
thinking -- either 0 or 2. They know the number is 0, or 00 in binary. They 
calculate their hat is white.

Third person knows to choose the lower number from whatever they are 
thinking -- either 0 or 1. The know the number is 0, or 00 in binary. They 
calculate their hat is white.

Sound good?

time black is called the parity switches for everyone left.

right. It couldn't be more obvious than that.
2. The number of all possible scenarios.

possibilities. Now for the first one we need to find these 2 numbers. Let's 
start with the number of scenarios in which all are right. Well, that is 1

arrange these 5 people - the 4 right ones are identical to each other so

arranging them and for each of those 5 ways we have 1 way of them getting 4 
out of 5 right where the wrong one is a particular one and not just any of 
them. We multiply 5 by 1 and we get 5. So finally we add 5 with 1 (the 
number of scenarios in which all are right) and we get 6. So we have 6 
scenarios in which at least 4 out of 5 are right. And finally as I said in 
the beginning we divide that by the number of all possible scenarios and we 
get: 6/(2*2*2*2*2)=3/(2*2*2*2)=18.75%

All the haters, you don't understand. I'll try clarifying: This video was 
sponsored by Always, for their campaign #LikeAGirl (as seen at the end of 
the video). That's why the animation focused on young girl confidence; 
that's the campaign's target.

For more context, here's what happened in a video for the campaign: Some 
very young (10yo and below), and some older (16yo and above) girls were 
asked to mimic various actions "like a girl" (run like a girl, fight like a 
girl, ...). The young girls would mimic passion, whereas the older ones 
would mimic clumsiness, ridiculousness.
That's what the campaign fights: "like a girl" has become synonym of 
"badly" for many people. The source of such a problem is not easy to 
pinpoint, of course. However, if "like a girl" becomes bad, then it implies 
empowering "like a boy" (in a simplified fashion).

Back to the video: The script is obviously general, and it has several 
complicated terms - "Social pressure" being one of them. Considering that 
representing "social pressure" on a person is not easy, and that the 
campaigns fights the bad nature of "like a girl", the choice of male 
pressure on the girl, seems like a justified choice. It's *a* way to 
represent social pressure relatively clearly, and fitting the #LikeAGirl 
campaign.

To those who ask "Why didn't the video include ... ?" I say it's probably 
because Pascal's triangle contains a wealth of patterns beyond belief. It 
is intricately linked to prime numbers, composite numbers, powers, 
triangular numbers, square numbers, pyramidal numbers, sums of pyramidal 
numbers (tetrahedral numbers), sums of sums of pyramidal numbers 
(pentagonal numbers), ... , Fibonacci and Lucas numbers, factorials, 
probability, combinatorics, and a whole host of more esoteric mathematical 
topics. Yet, in spite of its richness, it is easy to construct and explore.

For those who like a challenge, I suggest trying to find ways to:

(a) construct a row directly without constructing the rows above it;

(b) find formulae for the numbers in the "spine" (1, 2, 6, 20, 70, 252, 
...) and the adjacent columns (1, 3, 10, 35, 126, 462, ...);

(c) find formulae for some of the diagonals (1, 3, 6, 10, 15, 21, ...; 1, 
4, 10, 20, 35, ...; etc.).

Perhaps you could also try constructing and exploring alternative additive 
triangles, such as, for example:

Row 0 0 1 1
Row 1 0 1 2 0 
Row 2 0 .1. 3 2 0
Row 3 0 1 4 .5. 2 0
Row 4 0 1 5 9 7 .2. 0
Row 5 0 1 6 12 16 9 2 .0.

Let's look at some quirks and limitations in human language and see how we 
can work out a picture.

1. Intentionality. We humans are generally limited to fifth-order 
intentionality. At first-order intentionality, an animal is self-aware ('X 
knows that X knows'). At second-order intentionality, an animal is able to 
infer the thoughts of another ('X thinks that Y knows'). At third-order 
intentionality, an animal is able to lie intentionally and communicate to 
change another animal's thoughts about it ('X thinks that Y thinks X 
knows'). Fourth-order intentionality and beyond, often found in literature, 
can start to tax a human's mind.

An alien with more brain power could go beyond. The implication then is 
that this alien society would be highly interconnected, since they would be 
capable of managing long chains in a huge relationship web (e.g. 'Alice 
guesses that Bob knows that Carrol thinks that Denise doesn't care that 
Elaine suspects that Frank is lying to George'). Such a society would be 
able to grow huge without everyone becoming strangers as in human society.

2. Phonology is more generative than required in human language. What this 
means is that any random arrangements of possible sounds or their sign 
equivalents in human language almost always result in non-words; we only 
make use of a very small subset of possible combinations as real words.

A highly intelligent alien species could probably do amazing things with 
that extra generativity. It might allow them to bypass the problem of 
limited time and memory by binding long strings to nonwords, similar to 
what we do in programming, binding values to variables and groups of 
statements to functions. Humans are able to do this to a limited extent in 
writing, but it is error-prone and doesn't come naturally. A more advanced 
alien could take this to the next level.

3. Human language is very lossy and makes up for it in redundancy. It's a 
generalized broadcast system that is also supposed to work in noisy 
environments. The result is that it doesn't perform particularly well 
either as a pure broadcast system or a private communications system. 
Speaking to a roomful of people requires a loud voice and good acoustics, 
while trying to talk privately can also be tricky. Whispering and furtive 
signs are easily misunderstood, but increasing the signal risks others 
overhearing.

An alien communication system may have more sensitive organs or more 
powerful filtering systems to allow for more compressed messages. It may 
also specialize so that broadcast communication is fundamentally 
differentiated from private communication. Encryption and decryption might 
even be part of an alien communication system.

4. Discreteness. Human language is theoretically discrete, but speech and 
signs are largely continuous signals that have to be parsed and recreated 
by every listener. An alien communication system may be highly discrete. 
This may reduce listener-based errors that accumulate in human language and 
eliminate a factor in rapid language change.

With sufficient compression of the source message and little room for fuzzy 
interpretation, the hypothetical alien language may stay stable for a very 
long time, unlike human language, which can turn unrecognizable within a 
millennium.

Actually, it's more like older versions of English case marked everything, 
but over time that was dropped, except on pronouns. We Have actually lost 
some of the case marking on the second person pronouns, but that happened 
because (as has happened in a lot of (western?) European languages, the 
plural and singular got tangled up with politeness/formality, and the more 
intimate Singular second person pronoun was eventually dropped entirely. 
"Thou" made All the same distinctions that "I" does, while plural "you" 
made, and makes, less. Anyway, it does serve a purpose: it allows for more 
types of agreement, allowing for more redundancy, meaning less information 
is lost when the signal to noise ratio increases due to, say, strong winds, 
crowds, etc. It also allows more Precision, which is useful in, say, legal 
contexts (if they had much use for standard pronouns in the first place, 
that is.) Basically, there is a difference, for all that it's purely 
grammatical, not semantic, and it is useful. I'll grant it's not Necessary 
though.

"Robbers, who steal chocolate bunnies rapidly, attract the outrage of 
onlookers," suggests that all robbers rapidly steal chocolate bunnies. 
"Robbers, who steal chocolate bunnies, rapidly attract the outrage of 
onlookers." does the same thing. 
"Robbers who steal chocolate bunnies, rapidly attract the outrage of 
onlookers" is incorrect because if you take out the prepositional phrase it 
becomes a command: "Robbers, rapidly attract the outrage of onlookers." 
("Robbers" takes on a different function in the sentence; instead of being 
a subject, it's the person being addressed in a command.)

"shredding" as a playing style embodied by Dimebag Darrell, Kerry King and 
Yngwie Malmsteen, they don't define the style itself. Jimmy Page could 
shred, Jimi Hendrix did pretty much nothing but shred, and Kurt Cobain was 
known for shredding the hell out of his guitar when he wasn't playing 
something slower or something more sugary. Sure Hendrix and Cobain didn't 
really employ sweep picking or 64th notes at 3000 bpm, but that's not all 
shredding is. People seem to forget that "guitar shredding" has been around 
since the 70s. It is literally defined as playing a distinctive lead style 
very well. Even B.B. King could shred, and he played like ten notes a 
minute. lol

A written record may encode a stage of a language corresponding to an 
earlier time, either as a result of oral tradition, or because the earliest

millennium. An extreme case is the Vedic Sanskrit of the Rigveda: the 
earliest parts of this text may date to c. 1500 BC,[1] while the oldest 
known manuscript dates to the 11th century AD, a gap of over 2,500 years.

anything. The distinction you're making is pretty nuanced, but I think the 
"hard problem" involves both. "Whether" a nonhuman animal experiences a 
given state, and "how we can know" whether an animal experiences such a 
state. THAT nonhuman animals experience states is a given for philosophers 
like Nagel and Chalmers. HOW WE KNOW (or don't know) those states is the 
real problem. In other words, it is both a problem of matter and an 
epistemological problem: Does a fish feel pain? Who knows--probably, but 
the real question is, what is the fish's experience of the feeling of pain?

measurable quanta. In my view, the "hard problem" is a way of pointing up 
the limits of scientific investigation to produce answers to basic 
questions.
